headline: Hot Italian Giardiniera
description: This giardiniera recipe is a hot, tangy pickled pepper, olive, and jalapeño topping for Italian beef sandwiches, sausages, French dips, and pasta.

video.description: It’s the tangy, spicy pickled-pepper topping for sausages and beef sandwiches.
video.name: Hot Italian Giardiniera

name: Hot Italian Giardiniera
recipeIngredient: 1 (5 ounce) jar pimento-stuffed green olives, chopped

recipeInstructions.text: Place green and red peppers, jalapeños, celery, carrots, onion, and cauliflower in a large bowl. Stir in salt, then fill with enough cold water to cover. Place plastic wrap or aluminum foil over the bowl; refrigerate for 8 hours to overnight.
Drain salty water; rinse vegetables and set aside.

Mix together olives, garlic, oregano, red pepper flakes, and black pepper in a medium bowl. Pour in vinegar and olive oil; mix well. Combine with vegetable mixture; cover and refrigerate for 2 days before using.

review.reviewBody: I love this recipe and I definitely took the advise of other to change the oil to vinegar ratios. I used 1 cup Vinegar, 1/2 cup vegetable oil and 1/2 cup olive oil. Comes our perfect t each time!

I've lived in Chicago for over 30 years, and have become hooked on hot giardiniera. This is hands down the best one ever. I have made it about a dozen times, and everyone I know loves when I have a new batch ready. I use peppers from my garden, so sometimes they are not too spicy, and sometimes they melt your face off. A tip I wanted to share if your peppers are too spicy: adding more carrots, cauliflower and some diced jicama helps absorb some of the spice plus adds a nice crunch. It's fun to pick the red jalapeños and Serranos to make a unique batch of red giardiniera. You can't go wrong with this recipe. This is amazing on scrambled eggs, baked potatoes and pretty much anything else.
Yummy! I left the seeds out of the jalepenos since ours were kind of hot and ours came out mild but delicious. Thank you! We have missed our good Italian food from Chicago.
Tried this recipe for the first time and it was GREAT. After a few days I noticied it started to "separate" has anyone else expierenced this? Trying to figure out why

Thank you! I've been making this recipe for over 10 years. My modifications: 

1. I use a lot less oil -- maybe 2:1 vinegar to oil instead of 1:1 -- and I use half olive oil and half regular vegetable/canola oil. That way it doesn't solidify in the fridge.
2. I make a mild version. Even though I like spicy foods, I rarely use the jalapeno (usually because I don't typically have it on hand). You can use whatever vegetables you want, I usually stick to cauliflower, carrots, celery, and red bell peppers. 

YUM!

Everyone loves this! They claim it's the perfect giardiniera...they eat it straight out of the jar. At first, I was afraid that the 1/2 cup of salt called for to soak veggies in was WAY too much? But after all was combined, and left to sit in the oil and vinegar, it turned out perfect. Just be sure to rinse veggies after they are done soaking really good.
Forgot to add that I actually used cider vinegar and added a touch more than the recipe called for. I think I’ll add more cauliflower next time too. I love a salad with a kick!

This is a terrific recipe that closely mimics Vienna's Hot Giardiniera. I followed the recipe to the letter until tasting. At that point I added diced serrano peppers to achieve the heat level I was striving for. I have experienced a similar issue with recipes calling for jalapeno peppers prior to this recipe as there is a high degree of variance in heat level in Jalapenos. Serranos while not being overly hot are very consistent in the heat each pepper adds to the mix. Overall everyone loves the results of this recipe & enjoys the salad mix in many different ways. Great Recipe.
I made this but it didn’t marinate since the oil solidifies in fridge. Taste nothing like Giardiniera

My sons LOVE this- a great way to add fresh veggies to salad too! When using only olive oil (and vinegar) I found that the liquid solidifies somewhat; I use 1/2 cup olive oil, 1/2 cup corn oil and 1 cup white vinegar. There is less solidification that way!!
Awesome recipe! Only modification was that I used 1/2 the recommended amount of black pepper.

So, here I am, munching on my first batch of this recipe as I write this review. Pretty much stayed with the original recipe. Perhaps I was a little over enthusiastic about rinsing. After adding back in a little salt, it was REALLY good. I will definitely make this recipe again, and when I do, I will try it without going through the "rinse cycle".

Love it! Gave much of my first batch away and got lots of raves. My sons, who live(d) in Chicago give it 5 stars and love the fact you can adjust to suit your particular tastes, as evidenced by other reviewers. I stuck to the recipe as written the first time but will adjust with veggies I have on hand and maybe a bit less salt this time around. Thank you!

Simply Amazing!!!

I may be breaking protocol. But I am not an olive fan. I made this with banana peppers in place of olives. I also swapped 3 of the jalapeños out with serano peppers and added more cauliflower. 

Simply amazing!!! I have eaten it with literally everything and plan on making more. Great recipe!!!
Just made it today and it smells so good! I might not be able to wait two days!
Fantastic! I eat it right out of the jar.

This is about as good as it gets. My veggie mix was larger and different - lots of celery and cauliflower along with carrots, garlic, onion, jalapenos, Greek peppers (Peperoncini) green and black olives, fennel and coriander added also along with yellow mustard seed. Add any veggies you like - it's you mix and you'll be happy - Very Happy !

Thank you for sharing this recipe! Five star plus. It is wonderful and I will not ever be buying jarred giardiniera again. It is easy to make and full of flavor. I have to admit, some of it didn’t make it into the fridge.
Omg never heard of this and my husband found this. Made as instructed. Had this on a sweet Italian sausage sandwich. This is amazing. Going to mason jar this for Christmas Gifts! Delicious!!!!
Mind got a thick white paste on top,
Easy and awesome!!!
Less bell peppers more cauliflower, just a preference. Everyone at the party loved it!

I kinda like how it turned out. Not as much flavor or pickleyness as I would like. But it is interesting that the veggies don't need to be cooked and still come out like they've been blanched. With the oil in there, mine is not clear like the picture. Tweak time.
Great recipe. Based upon your preferences, you can change it up to suit your liking.
I used ghost peppers, red jalapeno peppers with seeds and habanero peppers. I didn't add red pepper seeds. Vinegar cuts back on some of the hotness. I loved it but obviously not for everyone.

Delicious! This first time I cut the ingredients fine because I was thinking of a relish. I think I will try to squeeze in another this year and make it bigger pieces for an appetizer. I also had no celery first time through and that's gonna change because I love celery. I took out the seeds from the jalapeno peppers, and a week later it is nearly mellow. All in all I love this stuff!

Great recipe. Lot of people raving about his on the first batch. 
 Doubled the olives first time and will try cutting the oil on the second try only to make it healthier.
Nothing else is like this......thanks for the recipe
This is really good. I didn't really change a thing other than to seed my jalapenos as I didn't want this to be super spicy. I have been eating this on nearly everything. It's so good.
Incredibly good. I upped the spice by using way too many serrano chili’s. I find myself eating it right out of the jar by the spoonful! This will be a regular staple at our house.
This was delicious! I used more cauliflower and jalapeños but that’s the way we roll! Tasted like the store bought brand that we’ve eaten for years. Thank you for posting this recipe.
smells wonderful...tastes even better
So delicious!!!
I added Golden Greek Pepperoncini

I made this for Italian beef sandwiches and it was so good! I added some Italian seasoning herbs and made one jar very spicy with red pepper flakes. People were eating this by the spoonful at my party.

Not bad, but it was lacking pepper. Try using 3-4 tablespoons of flour to thicken it up. Instead of water, use Sloe Gin. Goes well over navy beans. Try these modifications and I guarantee a FIVE STAR delight! Enjoy!

Great recipe! I love the brining step. I halved the vinegar and used jarred pepperoncini juice to make a cup. What got me started was Joe Amorosini's video as a News7 Christmas special but one has to buy the recipe through an obscure process. I say more cauliflower. Pic of brining jug included.
Figured it out and this was a delicious jar of Hot Veggies. My friends loved it too! Thanks for sharing this great recipe!!
No, yes
This is the best recipe I have made! I doubled the olive content! I love olives! Thanks!
I live this recipe , HOWEVER this time my fresh outta the garden . jalapeno made it a little to warm ..any suggestions to tame the heat..
When I make this again, and I will, I will use vegetable oil in place of the olive oil.
No changes yes will make it again
I am obsessed with pickling right now. I added in a clove of garlic cut in half and a bay leaf to each jar. I love this on Italian beef sandwiches!
If you are looking to can this, there is a very similar recipe in the 31 st Edition of the Ball Blue Book to home canning. You do have to leave out the oil.
Recipe is excellent! We have decided to try more veggies next time such as radishes and asparagus.
Fantastic!

I made it following the recipe, plus one additional jalapeño. My Italian husband loves it, says it's the best he's ever had. He's had it on burgers, Italian subs, and just by itself. Great recipe! Thanks for sharing!

I made an extra hot version with some of my own pepper hybrids. Turned out amazing and can't wait to have on an italian beef or some pizza. 
Celery, cauliflower, poblanos, jalapenos, ghostly penos, white bhut peppers, my El Scorponero, red pepper, scotch bonnets, cow horns ect, Used cane and white wine vinegar instead of plain distilled.
tasted like veggies in vinegar. didnt have flavor except heat. not what I dreamed it would be. Still on my giardiniera quest. *sigh*

This is wonderful, I made it according to the recipe but then added spices to the bottom of each jar before sealing. There is a lot of discussion on whether it is safe to can this, the answer is yes, just do not add the oil.
Absolutely delicious.
Absolutely delicious.

Great basic recipe. As stated, this recipe can (and should) be customized to your own tastes (and what ingredients you happen to have that day). Mine is in the fridge right now "cooking" for the next two days.

Made it as a Christmas gift for my husband as I don’t like anything in this recipe but he LOVES them all. Followed the recipe exactly and it was a great hit. It made 2 quart jars and it will likely be gone in 2 days. Will make it again.
Easy, delicious, and adjusts well to whatever crunchy veggies I have on hand. Great with a variety of rice dishes too.

Very tasty... very fresh.. 
The mistake I made was emptying the entire 5.7oz bottle of olives with juice into the mixture. Should've drained the juice and maybe sliced the olives. 

The olive juice is too present/up front in my mixture. Truthfully, I don't mind that.. but its a bit overpowering considering the amount of vinegar. I'm pretty certain the flavors would have been more balanced without the olive juice.

I made this mixture specifically for homemade Italian beef sandwiches.. I was hoping to convert my wife and sons to the joy of the Italian Beef... I got one of three... kinda! LOL
Like so many others we loved this. Enough heat for us. We never had this before and reviews were so great I needed to try and glad I did.

This is delicious! I also added fresh halved mushrooms, and 1 inch pieces of fresh green beans and wax beans. All my vegetables were roughly chopped- so this could be a finger food snack. I canned this in a hot water bath for 25 minutes for quarts leaving out the oil. I add oil to the mixture after I open up the canned quarts. This is hot but not TOO hot and the taste is awesome! I will definitely make this again next year when the garden is ready for harvest!
This turned out great!
Keep the seeds and hold the carrots, cauliflower & olives best stuff e

I asked my sister to make this one day when I knew she was looking for something fun to do. We both loved it, and since she and I have both made several batches. She makes this delicious giardiniera to give as gifts. She also puts it on quesadillas. I make it for my family. We put it on rice, pasta, and pizza, and my husband mixes it in sour cream to tone down the heat and likes it as a side dish with sausage. I also use it as an Italian-style salsa with chips. Yum!

Lordy,Lordy this is so good, my first attempt at it and the neighbors are asking for more! One change I made was to use Canola oil because it will not congeal and solidify like olive oil will. I have never tasted any better.
I added fresh basil and parsley. Added 3 large jalapenos instead of 8.
Great recipe, Excellent

I loved this recipe though I did make a few changes based on our taste preferences. First, since I had thought the store giardiniera was way too salty, I made sure I rinsed mine very well after I took it out of the fridge. Next, I did use Canola oil as others suggested since I knew I would be keeping it in the fridge and olive oil solidifies in the fridge. Finally, I only put in three jalepenos, but even that was too spicy for my husband so I may put in even fewer next time--or make us separate batches. 
I took some to share with my son and daughter-in-law and they too loved it. I will be making this again--soon.
I haven't even made this and I know its "The Kind". No sugar. First thing I checked. I'm making a batch for my Muffaletta sammies.

This is, quite frankly, one of the best! I made the first batch exactly as written with the exception of a bit larger veggies. For my personal preference, I wasn't crazy about the garlic. My husband loved it! Second batch, I left garlic out and added a bit more cauliflower and some hot banana peppers and used a blend of canola and olive oil. It's really hard to stay out of the jar. Thanks for a truly delicious recipe!
This is fantastic!! Always have some ready to eat in the fridge.
Absolutely delicious! I ate the entire batch in 4 days. Making batch number 2 today. It's very rare that I don't tweak a recipe but this didn't need it. Thanks for posting!
This is easy and delicious.I found it a bit to spicy for my taste. My husband and brother in law,however could get enough,ate it by the dish!
Absolutely love this recipe!!

Nice. I replaced the cauliflower with thickly shredded cabbage. It gives it more stability than cauliflower floweretts rolling off a sandwich. Better and easier crunch than biting through a chunk of cauliflower. I will likely add black olives next time also. Yum! I used canola oil.

I made this with a few change after reading reviews. I used about 2 cups of cauliflower, 1 large red bell pepper, 1/2 onion, 2 carrots, 5 jalapinos and 2 stalks of celery. I soaked veggies with 1/4 cup of salt for a day. Even after draining and rinsing veggies very well, there was still a very prevelent taste of salt. I then used about 4 ounces of the olives and about 3/4 cup of distilled vinegar and canola oil, along with the oregano, red pepper flakes, pepper. Overall it was very good. While I don't love salt, next time I will decrease salt and maybe mix in some black olives too.
I love this!!!
No changes that I can remember.... Made about 12 to 16, 1 pint jars of this in May, and I've got 2 left. My friends have worn me out over this!?? Thanks for the recipe!!

This is very good. My husband can't eat spicy food anymore
(too many years of eating spicy food) so I eliminated the hot peppers and added other peppers and it still tasted good.
Made as written and it was amazing! Making it a second time tonight, as the first batch didn't last long!
I've made this twice now...it's not just for Italian Beef anymore! You can use this as a topping on pasta, burgers, dogs, pizza, you name it!
Makes a lot! My husband absolutely loved this recipe. Great flavor. I'll never be able to buy the jar stuff again.

FABULOUS. Served this on Chef John's Chicago inspired italian hot beef sandwiches and it was great! My husband raved about it. I've also eaten by itself and with other meats/dishes and it's great! Thanks for the great recipe.

So incredibly good. I'm also from Chicago, and although it's not Portillo's style, it's so good I stand around and eat this stuff with a spoon right in front of the refrigerator. I also only used about 3 hot peppers because I want to be able to enjoy it without crying.

I made it exactly as is and it was less spicy than I thought. I do wonder about canning it as it made quite a bit and I put it in jars. The olive oil does solidify in the fridge but it still tastes fine. Made some great gifts.
so yummy on sandwiches
no changes necessary! perfect, and perfectly simple!
The olive oil solidified in the fridge. I read someone's review to use veggie oil instead of olive oil. I will try that next time. Otherwise very yummy. I added banana peppers too.

I love this recipe. I'm Italian and have eaten this in different ways but never thought it could be so easy to make. I did change it a bit, I didn't have green peppers so only used orange bell peppers, I don't like green olives so I omited them but added mushrooms. I didn't have jalapeños but did have fresh red chili peppers (I didn't add seeds, concerned it would be too spicy). I like a bit more vinegar flavour so I added 1/4 cup less olive oil and added 1/4 cup more white vinegar. I also doubled the recipe, jarred and put them in hot water bath for 5 minutes so that it will keep. So, so yummy...Thank you for sharing
We do a triple batch, jar it and keep it all winter. We used last jar 1 week before we make the next batch, I leave it in salt brine full 24 hrs before adding remainder of ingredients. Love results
This is the second time I've made this fantastic recipe, this time I used vinegar with 10% acidity purchased from a Polish deli.
Fantastic!
Awesome! Its delicious but for me I added a few more jalopenos...lol I like a lot of heat!
As a Chicagoan this a staple in our refrigerator. But this recipe blows away any store bought brands and is perfect for items from the garden.
Made this for the first time for my husband and its amazing how easy it is to put together.

LOVE IT so much we are eating it with chips! I too have relocated from Chicago and finished the last of the supply I brought with me. Never thought of making it myself. I substituted jalapeños with serrano peppers, and ended up using 3x the oil, vinegar and garlic. 1 c of oil and vinegar was not enough to cover the 4 bell peppers. I also used canola oil instead of olive oil. Thanks.

I made this for a BBQ we were hosting where we cooked up Italian Sausages. I prepared the recipe according to the directions (minus most of the hot peppers). I didn't want it to be too crunchy. So I cooked the relish in a saute pan for about 5 minutes prior to serving so it would soften just a bit.

My husband is a Chicago native and every time we go back to visit, we make a Bari's run to stock up on their medium and hot giardiniera. When I needed a milder version for a dinner party, I used this recipe -- and we like it even better. The big difference is that instead of running the jars through a canning process, I just stick them in the back of the fridge for up to six months. As long as the vegetables are submerged in the briny oil, they stay crunchy, bright and beautiful. For those of you who find the oil off-putting, consider this. As we use the "fresh" giardiniera, I pour that yummy oil into another container and repurpose it as a fabulous secret ingredient in pizza/foccacia dough and Italian soups. I also brush it on split rolls and toast them in the oven to elevate my Italian Beef sandwiches. (The modifications I apply to this recipe are omitting the saltwater soak, adding a 12 oz jar of sliced pepperoncini/banana peppers, and substituting canola oil for olive oil.)

Loved it!!
Used 1/2 cup of white wine vinegar and 1/2 cup of balsamic vinegar.
Excellent

Love this recipe! I left out the cauliflower and carrots simply because I had none on hand. I ended up with a wonderful accompaniment to go with my fried calamari & plan to serve it in the future with bean soup, salmon & many other things.

Oh wow !! All I can say is I normally do not like pickled anything. Yet this recipe caught my eye and I thought I'd make it for family. Tried it. It just made my mouth so happy. I did however drop the jalapenos from the recipe.

The first time making this I followed the recipe exactly and it was delicious. Everyone has their own vegetable preferences so I've since added a lot of extra variety there. Cherry peppers, okra, cucumber and mushrooms are some of my favorite things to add. And I only ever use canola oil, which doesn't solidify in the fridge the way olive oil does.
